title: Boy, 12, doused in nail polish remover and set alight in terrifying ‘fire challenge’
text:

A mum is warning other parents about a terrifyingly reckless social media 'challenge' which sees children douse themselves in flammable liquid and set it alight.

Tabitha Cleary "freaked out" when she found her 12-year-old son on the back of his friend's bike with no shirt on after hearing screaming.

She ran outside to find him burned on his chin, chest and stomach.

Doctors said the lad suffered second degree burns.

Jason was at his friend's house when he was sprayed with nail polish remover and lit on fire during the so-called 'fire challenge'.

Tabitha, from Dearborn Heights, Michigan, told US news outlet WDIV ClickOnDetroit that her son had tried to do the challenge twice.

She said: "I just want everybody to know that these challenges, or whatever they’re watching on YouTube, is not worth risking your life."

Nail polish remover contains acetone, which is highly flammable.

(Image: NBC)

(Image: NBC)

Jason said: "The first time it was like a little tiny fire, then they swatted it out.

"Then the second time it [engulfed me] and they kept spraying it on me."

His traumatised mum said she "came running out. That's when we saw his friend Bryce riding him on the bike with no shirt on.

"I start to freak out. 'Take him to the hospital, take him to the hospital.' I'm crying. He's crying."

Jason spent four days in hospital and his mum now wants to raise awareness to stop this craze.

(Image: NBC)

(Image: NBC)

A reckless and dangerous viral craze

Hospital bosses have warned that more and more teenagers are seriously injuring themselves by taking part in online challenges that encourage them to set themselves on fire.

The craze is popular among young people hoping to become social media stars, but unsurprisingly has led to an increase in cases of serious burns.

Specialist staff at Morriston Hospital, in Swansea, have acknowledged it is becoming a big problem.

Many patients have been left with lifelong scars, a plastic surgeon confirmed.

(Image: NBC)

More cases are being seen by medical experts because of the craze, which originally began in 2014 and has been picked up again.

While the hospital did not wish to provide details of the different challenges, a quick search online reveals the scale of the problem.

One challenge, known online as the Fire Challenge, is literally as crazy as it sounds.

Youngsters are challenged to pour liquid on themselves and set themselves on fire.

This has resulted in people requiring surgery and life-support treatment.

Mirror Online previously reported that in August, a 12-year-old girl from Detroit burned 49 per cent of her body in the dangerous trend.

Timiyah Landers was with two friends at her home in Michigan, and her mother Brandi had just made them pancakes.

However minutes after she left the girls alone, there was a 'loud bang' and Timiyah was engulfed in flames.

Her stepfather immediately put her in a bath and splashed water on her body as her mother tore off her burning clothes.

Timiyah was taken to hospital and put on a ventilator in intensive care, with her body bandaged from head to her knees.

Abertawe Bro Morgannwg University Health Board is issuing a warning and some advice to anyone who has taken part in any of these challenges online.

“I can understand there is pressure on young people to gain acceptance or boost their online profiles by doing such risky things as these challenges,” said Jeremy Yarrow, a plastic surgeon at Morriston Hospital.

“But from the patients I see, the results can be very different, with some requiring life support treatment and many left with lifelong scars.”

Mr Yarrow added that while most teenagers presenting with burns are treated as outpatients, some are hospitalised for a considerable length of time.

“In some severe and sometimes life-threatening cases, they are admitted to hospital for long periods of time for complex surgery resulting in long term mental and physical issues,” he said.

While the health board would not release specific details of the challenges doing the rounds online, they did confirm that there are “various” ones being attempted by teenagers.

Ana Biney, a staff nurse at Morriston Hospital's Welsh Centre for Burns and Plastic Surgery, said: “They copy them from social media and YouTube and call them YouTube Challenges.

“They film each other doing the challenges and then upload them in the hope they will become social media stars.

“We have definitely seen an increase in the number of teenagers who have suffered quite serious burns because of this.”

Staff at the Burns Centre have offered the following advice for anyone affected with burns:

put the affected area under cool water for 20 minutes, as this takes the heat out of the injury

if clothing is on fire, the affected person should immediately drop to the floor and roll to put out the flames - don’t pat them out as this causes burns to the hands

cover the burn with cling film – never cotton wool – which protects the burn but allows doctors or paramedics to look at it.

call for help, which could be 999 or 111 or your GP

Ms Biney added: “Good first aid is essential. If you do it right, it can have a massive effect on the burn.

“But of course the best thing to do is not to take part in these stunts in the first place. They may look exciting and spectacular on social media but the reality is very different.

“They could be killed or scarred for life.”
description: A mum has issued a warning to parents about the dangerous social media craze after her son's friend set him alight and he suffered terrible burns
